desc: Test your knowledge of film terminology and practical analysis.
name: DIAGNOSTIC

desc: Learn more about films and terminology
name: Film terminology

segments.text: Far from exhaustive, but this exercise will help you learn some of the terms of the film world
segments.title: DO - Xword

desc: In this lesson you will learn to analyse film and start to think like a director
name: Think like a director

segments.text: Enjoy the "Wrong Trousers" in a new way and learn to think like a director
segments.title: DO - Wallace and Gromit

desc: Design, implement and test a solution to a problem
name: ASSESSMENT - Coding UX/UI

segments.text: How can I demonstrate my knowledge of the design cycle and technology skillset for this project? Make a website! Here is an exemplar.
segments.title: Website example

segments.text: Project instructions and rubric.
segments.title: RUBRIC- How will I be graded?

segments.text: Your project in this unit is to design and implement a user interface to improve the user experience for an existing software product.
segments.title: READ - Problem Solving

desc: Computers love doing things over and over and over ...
name: Loops

segments.text: Complete as many problems using loops as you can
segments.title: DO - Codingbat

segments.text: Different video series this time. Good intro to while and for loops.
segments.title: WATCH - Loops

desc: Lists are a built in data type for storing ordered data. Very useful!
name: Lists

segments.text: Work through first one together and then do as many as you can
segments.title: DO - Codingbat list problems

desc: Time for a check in to how you are doing. Submit your notebook and complete a multiple choice test.
name: DIAGNOSTIC

segments.text: All topics from class notes, readings and keywords are fair game.
segments.title: Multiple choice test

segments.text: Are you paying attention and keeping good notes? Titles, dates, neatness and completion?
segments.title: Notebook check

desc: Functions let you re-use code. What if you want to re-use many functions? The answer is modules.
name: Modules

segments.text: Program the examples from the reading and adapt them to learn more
segments.title: DO - Examples

desc: Often you have calculations and operations you need to repeat. Don't repeat yourself, write a function!
name: Functions

segments.text: Do first warmup together and then work through warmup1
segments.title: DO - Codingbat

desc: Just like in your daily life, there is data to evaluate in Python. Use if elif else statements to test conditions and react accordingly.
name: Logical conditions

segments.text: The Canadian Computing Contest runs each February. Try out 2014 Junior problem 1# - Triangle Times
segments.title: DO - Triangle Times

desc: Numeric data in Python is handled as int or float data.
name: Numbers and math

segments.text: Get your math homework out and write a program to solve a problem.
segments.title: DO - Math homework

desc: Text data is stored in Python as strings, or text within double or single quotes.
name: String data

segments.text: Add a multi-line banner and single line comments to your Ascii Art hello world program.
segments.title: DO - Comment hello world

desc: Learn how to write your first Python program
name: Hello Python

segments.text: Get creative and print a fancy Hello World to the screen. You will probably experience "bugs" and will have to "debug" your program.
segments.title: DO - Ascii Art Hello World

segments.text: Run Hello World from the interpreter and from a source file
segments.title: DO - Hello World

desc: Computers are all around us. This unit will help you learn to code using Python.
name: Python Boot Camp

desc: Design, implement and test a solution to a problem
name: ASSESSMENT - Making

desc: Time for a check in to how you are doing. Submit your notebook and complete a multiple choice test.
name: DIAGNOSTIC

segments.text: Multiple choice quiz on technical and design topics
segments.title: MC quiz

segments.text: Are you paying attention and taking good notes?
segments.title: Notebook check

desc: Create something of your choice in Illustrator! This is your chance to experiment more fully with the software.
name: Lasercut genius hour

segments.text: Remember, cuts are .01 point in stroke width and RGB 255 0 0 and engravings are RGB 0 0 0. Have fun! Take screenshots of outcome.
segments.title: DO - Illustrator

segments.text: Check out some cool examples and write down some ideas. What would be the effort to create them?
segments.title: NOTES - Examples

desc: In this lesson you will learn the basics of making cuts and engravings using Adobe Illustrator.
name: Lasercut boot camp

segments.text: Re-create the simple example using Illustrator. Take annotated screenshots of any problems during the process for later.
segments.title: DO - Illustrator

segments.text: Make notes on how to make a simple 4x2 cm rectangle with a border engraving like my example using Illustrator. This takes 5 mins to cut.
segments.title: NOTES - Illustrator

segments.text: Objects may be laser cut directly from Adobe Illustrator .ai files and then printed using the Trotec software.
segments.title: NOTES - process

desc: Create something of your choice in TInkerCAD! This is your chance to experiment more fully with the software.
name: 3D Genius hour

segments.text: Take screenshots of your process so it can be documented and annotated later and submitted later in your web site.
segments.title: DO - document

segments.text: Import your .stl and slice it to a .gcode so your design will be a quality print, but not take an unreasonably long time.
segments.title: DO - Slice with Cura

segments.text: Tinker with TinkerCAD and then export to a .stl
segments.title: DO - Tinker with TinkerCAD

desc: In this lesson you will create a simple shape in TinkerCAD, export to STL and then slice using Cura into a .gcode file for printing.
name: 3D boot camp

segments.text: Open your .gcode file with TextEdit. What is a .gcode file? What is G1? G0? G92? M82?
segments.title: NOTES - .gcode file

segments.text: Download Cura 3.4.1 and create .gcode with from .stl wit < 1 hour of print time. This is your challenge! Screen shot your work for web site.
segments.title: DO - Cura .gcode

segments.text: Signup for cloud TinkerCAD and create simple 4x4 cube base and with a paraboloid top. Export to .stl for further processing.
segments.title: DO - TinkerCAD .stl

segments.text: What is the process for creating a 3D printable file?
segments.title: NOTES - Process
